11:14 am

BE11:14am

Suggests a penalty “far less” than the initial $14bn negotiating number tabled by the DoJ, though doesn't go into specifics.

BE11:15am

Citi -- neutral on DB -- says:

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The original consensus estimate (prior to the $14bn number emerging) was for a penalty in the range of $4bn for DB, based on what US peers had already settled for ($3bn MS, $4bn GS, $7bn C, $7bn JPM, $15bn BAC), and the perceived scale of DB’s involvement. Expectations are now higher after the $14bn scare.

Deutsche Bank has total litigation reserves of E5.9bn, of which we estimate E4bn relating to the RMBS case. Consensus estimates include a further E1.5bn litigation charge in 4Q16, E1.2bn 2017 and E0.3bn 2018 (total E3bn 4Q16-2018), likely to be mostly for the RMBS case (effectively allowing for a E7bn settlement).

DB’s fully-loaded Basel-3 ratio at 3Q16 was 11.1%, rising to 11.2% 4Q16, 11.7% 2017, 12.4% 2018 with consensus earnings expectations (including the E3bn extra litigation charges / consistent with a E7bn RMBS settlement). That trajectory just about gets DB to its 12.5% 2018 target. However it includes some benefit from the planned Postbank IPO, which continues to appear difficult to achieve. Any capital shortfall from Postbank, earnings, or heavier litigation charges, would leave a gap to be filled.

DB’s CEO has since his appointment in mid-2015 ruled out any external capital raising until the bank has settled its major litigation cases (US RMBS and Russia mirror trades). So with settlements done, the topic of capital raising could become more prominent.

BE11:15am

The other challenge for DB remains poor profitability. On 2018 earnings expectations the group appears to be heading for 5% RoTE as reported, 6% ex one-offs, and 7% ex one-offs and non-core, all of which are some way below its 10-12% cost of equity. Within that the core Global Markets business is the biggest user of capital but delivering the lowest returns (4% 2018E RoTE), and therefore continues to need further restructuring and redesign.

BE11:16am

And from the Credit Suisse side .....

11:16 am
BE11:16am

CS has total existing litigation reserves of SFr2.1bn, of which we estimate some SFr0.5bn relates to this US RMBS case. Consensus earnings estimates also allow for further litigation charges of Sfr0.7bn in 4Q16, Sfr0.7bn in 2017 and SFr0.2bn in 2018 (total SFr1.7bn 4Q16-2018), which would be consistent with a settlement just over $2bn.

CS currently has a 12.0% fully-loaded Basel-3 CET1 ratio, rising to 12.8% by 2018 with consensus earnings expectations (including the SFr1.7bn additional litigation charges, consistent with c$2bn settlement). A heavier settlement eg $4bn would bring the 2016 ratio down to 10.6% and the 2018 projection to 12.1%, which would be only just within the company’s target range of 12-13% for 2018 (Basel-3, redenominating to 10-11% Basel-4).

PM11:17am

Cheers for that

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 64.35, up 1.8 (+2.88%), High: 64.35, Low: 62.24, Volume: 45.47m
BE11:22am

Goldman incoming.

BE11:23am

Definitely Goldman. I've treble checked.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

According to the company, the transaction is expected to increase
revenues by c.£650 mn p.a. (c.4%) and NIM by c.10 bp. In addition, Lloyds
expects to realize significant cost synergies of c.£100 mn p.a., equating to
c.30% of the 2015 MBNA cost base. Lloyds expects the transaction to utilize
c.80 bp of CET1 capital. We note that the £1.9 bn purchase price assumes
£240 mn in respect of future PPI claims, with Lloyds’ exposure to PPI claims
from MBNA capped at this amount.
Lloyds expects the transaction deliver an internal return on investment of
c.17%, implying c.£320 mn accretion to underlying earnings from year 2
onwards (c.5%)

BE11:23am

The transaction allows Lloyds to increase its market share in UK credit
cards from c.15% to c.26%, second only to Barclays (27%).
In terms of financials, the company’s guidance implies the transaction is
broadly neutral, with a capital hit of c.6% (80 bp) broadly offset by a c.5%
earnings uplift. This being said, we note the transaction significantly
increases Lloyds’ exposure to credit cards at a time of heightened
uncertainty around the UK macroeconomic outlook. Credit cards are a
high-margin and higher-risk product segment with impairment trends
closely linked to changes in unemployment.
We are Sell-rated on Lloyds and our 12-month ROTE/COE-based price
target is 52p (last close 62.6p). Key risks to our price target and investment
thesis are reduced competition in the UK mortgage market and significant
incremental cost reduction.

BE11:24am

Is this a sensible time in the cycle to take on a load of unsecured debt?

11:24 am
BE11:24am

I mean, sure, it's cheap unsecured debt ....

BE11:25am

11:25 am

BE11:26am

Return on Investment of 17% implies sub 6x PE: Based on the H1'16
profit after tax of £123m and including the £100m cost synergies, we
calculate an underlying Net profit post synergies of c£320m for MBNA.
This equates to a 17% return on the £1.9bn consideration and implies that
Lloyds is paying a PE of 5.9x for MBNA. To us, this is substantially below
expectations, we have previously used a 10.5x PE multiple

BE11:26am

Impact on Lloyds financials: The transaction is expected to impact CT1 by
80bps compared to our estimate of 13.7% CT1 for FY'16 and relative to
Lloyds' guidance of 13.9% pre dividend incl. 50bps of CT1 generation
guided for Q4'16. It would also add £650m to revenue and increases NIM
by 10bps. Statutory EPS accretion of 3%/5% in years 1&2 rises to 7% on
our estimate of £320m fully including cost synergies on an underlying basis

Three key reasons...

PM11:28am

1. TNAV per share - a popular benchmark for investors – could face severe
headwinds of up to 35p over the next year or so. This could overwhelm earnings
and also drive up the multiple to over 0.9 times book, which given the long-term
return profile would make the shares less attractive.
2. Our base case is for 24p of EPS and ROTE of 8% in 2019E. We also see limited
distributions over the period to start 2019. This is not enough to justify a share
price above current levels in today's terms.
3. On a blue sky scenario we see EPS of 30p and ROTE of 11% in 2019. Further
assuming lower equity tier 1 targets and a 9% COE results in a valuation of 300p
in today's terms. This is appealing but not enough given the assumptions made -
which would benefit other banks as well.

BE11:44am

MEDIASET - As Mediaset remains key to Bollore's longer term strategy he is remaining aggressive on his intentions and has announced plans to increase Vivendi's stake from 20% to 30% in the company. The long term intention is to from a strong pan-European content producer by forming a partnership between Mediaset, Canal+ and TIMvision. Furthermore, I remain of the view that once both parties have formed stakes in their respective operations their focus will move to their main problem in Italy - SKY - and to counter SKY, Vivendi and Mediaset will reopen negotiations and reach an agreement in due course.

11:45 am

BE11:45am

SFR WAS NOT VIVENDI's DELIVERY PLATFORM OF CHOICE - FIBRE IS - As such assets such as SFR were disposed off and future investments were made in content and fixed delivery platforms such as Telecom Italia. As we had argued previously the next move for Vivendi will be a stake swap between canal + and Orange in order to gain access to Orange's network, followed by a deal with Telefonica.

BE11:46am

Which dovetails into the "televised sport is dying" argument ....

11:46 am
PM11:46am

BE11:46am

BE11:46am

A recent intensive study in UK highlighted that only around 25% of Pay-TV customers chose Sports and football programming as their main reason to subscribe to Pay-TV. Indeed over 60% of the customers were more interested in Entertainment programmes and movies. Vivendi is well aware of this which is the reason that their intention was never to solely acquire Mediaset Premium (main content European championship football), rather they wanted access to Mediaset's entertainment content including the new series about Pope Francis, with the intention to broadcast such programmes over Telecom's Italia network in Italy, France Telecom's network in France and all over Europe.

PM11:49am

BE11:50am

11:50 am
BE11:50am

PM11:51am

It's a murky world, generally -- but i think Playsafe illustrates how some companies are getting better at responding to short attacks

PM11:51am

11:51 am
PM11:51am

I have no idea about the underlying allegations -- cos i was on holiday

BE11:51am

Well, that's one way of looking at it.

BE11:51am

Though I don't think Paysafe's ability to generate cash was ever a question raised in the bear case.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

For the sake of retreading old ground, here' Canaccord on that bear case.

BE11:52am

(And if anyone should be getting better at responding to short attacks on its clients, it's Canaccord.)

BE11:53am

While the highlighted concerns are wide ranging, they can be bucketed into a few camps:
• Exposure to Bet365 alleged to be 50% of Paysafe's earnings. We estimate 20-22%.
• The wallet business (Neteller/Skrill) is linked to gambling in China. The company has
said there is no exposure to China from the wallet business.
• This earnings exposure is linked to illegal gambling activity in China and other regions
e.g. India.
• Ex Paysafe employees are alleged to be involved in entities participating in illegal
gambling activities with a direct link to Paysafe
• Highlighted regulatory risk for the pre-paid voucher business with the introduction of
AML 4 and 5. The company has explained the potential implications for new regulation
and the steps taken to mitigate that risk.
• Concern around FCF conversion. We believe this is linked to a misunderstanding of the
working capital related to payments.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Of all these concerns, we see the exposure to Bet365 and China as the crux of this
negative report. The company stated robustly that Bet365 is "nowhere near 50% of profit
after tax". The report uses what seem logical steps to derive profitability estimates, but
appears to forget that the processing activity from the Asian gateway is very different
from normal credit/debit card processing as it uses a network of third party operators.
This changes the cost dynamics materially and, per the company comments, results
in gross margin a little below the Group's. While it is difficult to be precise with cost
apportionment below the gross margin, the company's guidance plus ultra conservative
assumptions such as no depreciation or tax apportionment, leads us to reach an
estimate of 20-22% of the total PAT linked to Bet365.
Were this exposure to Bet365 to be zeroed, the stock would trade on 10.8x 2017E
earnings, or 8x EV/EBITDA. It currently trades on 6.4x EV/EBITDA and 8.4x P/E 2017E.
We maintain our BUY recommendation and 508p target price, derived from a SoTP
valuation using a discount to sector peer multiples on EV/EBITDA.

BE11:54am

... And Citi. Note, this is all historic stuff, as in from last week.

BE11:55am

A downside risk for Paysafe is its Asian Gateway used by its Major Merchant. It has been well flagged that the Major Merchant engages in Chinese-related gambling activities. Paysafe’s exposure to these activities accounts for less than 13% of group revenue (as at 1H17). Our calculations suggest the earnings exposure is 14-17% of FY16e Group EBITDA and 19-24% of FY16e Group Adjusted PAT (assuming no attributable D&A, Interest and Tax costs).

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Upcoming AML regulation is another common discussion topic. As we have previously discussed, the new AML directives will likely introduce additional KYC and registration requirements for the Paysafecard division. We view registration as a marginal inconvenience for Paysafecard customers, given their low transaction values (€24 average transaction size), which will typically only be subject to basic due diligence. However, the new directives will not reduce the distinct benefits that Paysafecard provides, such as the ability to pay online with cash and anonymity from credit records. Additionally, timing for the new AML 5 directive is still in draft stages, with the latest proposals suggesting an effective date in June 2017 and a likely delayed implementation period.

BE11:55am

We retain our Buy rating. We view the downside risks as being overplayed and see the discounted valuation as unwarranted. The shares now trade at a FY17e PE ratio of 8.4x and FY17e EV/EBITDA of 6.2x. If we completely exclude our estimated Asian Gateway earnings, the shares trade at a FY17e PE of 10.5x and EV/EBITDA of 7.1x (at the mid-point of our estimates). Paysafe is delivering on a solid earnings profile with +19% organic sales growth in FY16e and has been diversifying its China exposure.

PM11:56am

PM11:56am

PM11:57am

11:56 am
PM11:57am

Tech Winners Create New Categories, Which Eventually Apple Will Need to do Again

BE11:57am

Yeah, good to highlight these under-researched companies where clients might have an edge.

PM11:57am

Steven Milunovich the analyst

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Go on then.

PM11:57am

They're waiting for VR/AR, which I know you buy and I don't

PM11:58am

iPhone 8 good enough for now but then what?
Category creation is the brass ring in business. The best even become synonymous with the category—Kleenex, Xerox, and Google. Apple has been a serial innovator, but investors question whether Apple has lost its mojo. We don't think the answer will be clear for a few years because consumer tech is in a gap period in which the capabilities are not yet there to deliver VR/AR, autonomous cars, and even the Internet assistant. In Figure 1 Benedict Evans suggests that mobile is maturing with the next era possibly driven by augmented reality. Apple will need new product or service categories.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Category is the new strategy
The importance of category creation has been underscored a number of ways. Trout & Ries, the fathers of positioning, said the goal is own a word in the customer's mind as Intel does with "microprocessor." Peter Thiel advises start-ups not to fight incumbents through disruption but become monopolists in virgin territory. The recent book Play Bigger provides a how-to for category design. The authors update Trout & Ries teachings, such as different beats better and the CEO needs to be the chief category officer. They argue a company's value depends on the size of the category, company's share in the category, and delivering on promises to customers.

PM11:58am

The job to be done is critical to category creation
The authors express their hope that Apple can continue to be a category creator following on the iPod and iPhone. We have emphasized the importance of finding a job to be done from the customer's standpoint, at which Apple has proven adept (link). Scarcity Theory says new markets depend on the alignment of technology that creates a new scarcity (supply) with a higher-level job to be done (demand in Figure 2). We suggest that alignment is not yet in place for Apple's potential new jobs. Figure 3 shows the process of finding a job to be done and assuring that internal processes support the job. We add a fourth box, which is category design, including strategy and culture but also how the company presents itself externally.

BE11:58am

(@ROTR: we have a low tolerance for smut.)
